title: Two people grab the same coat
vignette: Two shoppers grab the same coat at the exact same moment and each insists it already belonged to them. No proof exists of prior ownership.

options.text: Have the coat appraised or sold and split the money equally.
Keep the coat in limbo until someone can show evidence that it was theirs first.

title: Mixed cash deposits
vignette: A clerk receives two sealed envelopes—one held $100 and the other $200—but forgets which customer left which amount.

options.text: Give $100 back to each customer and place the extra $100 in escrow until the facts are clarified.
Refund the customers in full from the clerk’s own funds and absorb any loss personally.

title: Finder before the owner knows
vignette: A passer-by picks up a bracelet lying on the sidewalk and suspects it was only recently dropped. The owner has not discovered it is missing yet.

options.text: The finder may keep it immediately, assuming the owner will soon give up hope of recovering it.
The finder must hold the bracelet until it is clear the owner notices and abandons hope, then may claim it.

title: Lost object during paid work
vignette: While on the clock, a farmworker notices a lost wallet on the ground. Picking it up would only take a few seconds.

options.text: The wallet belongs to the worker; items found are not part of her wages.
The wallet belongs to the employer because anything the worker handles during the shift counts as the employer’s effort.

title: One canteen in the desert
vignette: Two hikers are stranded far from help with only enough water for one person to finish the trek alive.

options.text: Share the water equally, risking that neither survives.
The person carrying the bottle drinks it all so at least one life is saved.

title: Over-loaded donkey collapse
vignette: A passer-by sees a donkey collapsed under a load that its owner piled on too heavily.

options.text: Help unload the donkey even though the owner caused the problem.
Do nothing; the owner’s negligence cancels any duty to assist.

title: What seals a sale?
vignette: A buyer has paid for goods still sitting in the seller’s yard when a fire starts.

options.text: Ownership passed with payment, so the buyer bears the loss.
Ownership passes only when the buyer physically removes the goods, so the seller bears the loss.

title: How much price fraud voids a sale?
vignette: A vendor charges 17 % above the going market price.

options.text: Any markup over 16 % cancels the sale and the buyer gets a full refund.
Overcharges are tolerated up to one-third; the buyer keeps the item and receives only a partial refund.

title: Hidden interest gift-loan
vignette: A lender gives a small "gift" before issuing a loan and the borrower promises a similar gift afterward.

options.text: Treat the gifts as disguised interest and forbid any extras beyond the loan amount.
Allow the gifts if they aren’t scheduled in advance and are presented as voluntary gestures.

title: Borrowed animal seized by troops
vignette: Someone borrows a mule, but soldiers commandeer it for military service.

options.text: The borrower is responsible for the loss unless the mule is eventually returned.
Responsibility depends on the direction the troops took it—sometimes the risk falls on the owner.

title: Forbidden route for hired donkey
vignette: A renter takes a hired donkey along a route the owner had forbidden, arguing the danger on that path is now gone.

options.text: Trust the renter; no liability if the path was indeed safe.
The renter pays for any harm because taking an unauthorized route is negligent.

title: Workers snacking in the field
vignette: Harvesters may eat some produce while picking. How much is appropriate?

options.text: Allow them to eat as much as they like during work.
Limit their eating to roughly the value of their daily wage.

title: Timely wages
vignette: A day laborer finishes at sunset, but the employer cannot pay until the next morning.

options.text: Payment by sunrise is still on time.
Wages are due the same night; any delay disrespects the worker.

title: Four custodians liability
vignette: An unpaid custodian, a paid custodian, a renter, and a borrower each lose an item under circumstances beyond their control.

options.text: Only the borrower must always pay; the others simply swear they were not negligent.
Who pays or swears depends on how much each was paid—more pay means more liability.

title: Share-cropper blight
vignette: A disease destroys half the crop on leased land.

options.text: The landowner bears the loss because it is his soil.
The tenant bears the loss because he accepted crop risk for a share of the harvest.

title: Clearing the communal canal
vignette: Silt blocks an irrigation canal serving an upper town first and a lower town downstream.

options.text: The lower town should dig first because they lose water immediately.
The upper town must dig first; otherwise no water reaches anyone.

title: Cost of a privacy fence
vignette: One neighbor wants to build a solid privacy wall; the other refuses to split the cost.

options.text: Force both to share the expense because both benefit from privacy.
Each may build only on their own side; no one can compel the other.

title: New window facing courtyard
vignette: A homeowner cuts a new window that directly overlooks a neighbor’s yard.

options.text: The neighbor can veto the window because it harms privacy.
The window is allowed if placed high enough to avoid direct viewing.

title: Squatter’s rights
vignette: Someone quietly lives rent-free in an unused apartment; the owner has no idea and loses nothing.

options.text: This is allowed—if the owner suffers no loss, no rent is owed.
This is forbidden; using property without consent is theft.

title: Words vs. money fraud
vignette: A merchant publicly humiliates a customer but overcharges him by only one dollar.

options.text: Verbal harm is worse than the small monetary fraud.
Both wrongs are equally serious and should be treated the same.

title: Donating a disputed bathhouse
vignette: During an argument over a shared bathhouse, one partner suddenly declares it is now donated to charity.

options.text: The donation is effective immediately; the other partner loses access.
The donation fails because ownership is still unclear.

title: Promissory note tug-of-war
vignette: A lender and a borrower each hold the same loan document—one says it is unpaid, the other says it is settled.

options.text: Split the claimed amount and have both parties swear to their statements.
The document must go entirely to whichever side can produce evidence.

title: “Pick it up for me!”
vignette: A person sees a watch on the ground and tells a friend, “Pick that up for me.”

options.text: The speaker acquires the watch through the friend’s action.
The friend keeps it; an agency request without prior consent is invalid.

title: Child finds coin for grandma
vignette: A child spots a lost coin and says they’re saving it for their grandmother.

options.text: The child can acquire the coin on someone else’s behalf, even while dependent.
Because the child is legally dependent, the coin belongs to the guardian by default.

title: Three coins as an identifying mark
vignette: A finder discovers exactly three coins neatly stacked on the sidewalk.

options.text: That specific pattern is distinctive enough to require announcing the find.
The number alone is not a true identifier; the finder may keep the coins.

title: Bailee repaid, thief caught: who gets double?
vignette: A guardian has already reimbursed the owner for a stolen vase. The thief is later caught and must pay double damages.

options.text: The owner receives the penalty because they originally bore the loss.
The guardian receives it since they became the real loser after repaying the owner.

title: Guardian hands deposit to another
vignette: An unpaid guardian quietly passes a stored item to a different keeper, and the item is lost.

options.text: The original guardian is liable because he changed the terms without permission.
Liability shifts to the new guardian once he accepted the item.

title: Earnest-money forfeiture
vignette: A buyer pays a 20 % deposit with a clause saying the deposit is forfeited if the buyer backs out.

options.text: The clause stands; the buyer loses the deposit if they retract.
Such forfeiture clauses are void; over-optimistic pledges don’t stick.

title: Boss vs. laborer retract first
vignette: Ten minutes after hiring day laborers, both the boss and the workers find better offers elsewhere.

options.text: Workers may quit with no penalty because they relied on finding better work.
Workers must stay or pay compensation since the boss’s loss is greater.

title: Guaranteed-principal investment
vignette: An investor supplies a goat but guarantees the original value while keeping all offspring profits.

options.text: Treat the deal as hidden interest and forbid it.
Allow it if the investor truly shares any loss risk.

title: Mountain vs. valley route hire
vignette: A renter takes a hired donkey on a mountain trail instead of the agreed valley path of equal length; the donkey breaks a leg.

options.text: Any unauthorized route change counts as negligence, so the renter pays.
The renter pays only if the new path is demonstrably rougher.
